channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Elected to United Nations Human Rights Council
item.description: Saying it would “oppose pressure and confrontation” on the United Nations Human Rights Council and advance the cause of human rights, China was elected to it for a three-year term along with Cuba, Saudi Arabia and Russia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Afghan Opium Cultivation and Production Seen Rising
item.description: Poppy cultivation and production hit record levels this year, and programs to counteract them have floundered, a new United Nations study said.
item.category: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Opium being smoked last month in Herat, Afghanistan.

item.title: Aid Groups in Philippines Fear Finding More Devastation
item.description: Relief organizations began ramping up their efforts Wednesday, facing daunting obstacles in areas where the scale of Typhoon Haiyan’s destruction is unknown.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: U.N. Appeals for $301 Million Toward Typhoon Relief
item.description: The appeal for emergency assistance came a day after the top United Nations relief official flew to the Philippines to help lead the global response.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Oxfam employees prepared and checked aid to be shipped to the Philippines on Tuesday at a warehouse in Bicester, England.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Colorful History of a Power Hotel in Beijing
item.description: The Jingxi Hotel, where Chinese leaders met this week, has a colorful history hosting some of the most important gatherings in modern Chinese history.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Chinese security personnel guard the entrance to the Jingxi Hotel.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Greenpeace Protesters Taken to St. Petersburg Prisons
item.description: The 30 people arrested after a Greenpeace protest at a Russian oil rig in the Arctic were transferred to prisons in St. Petersburg on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: New U.N. Rights Council Members Are Elected
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly elected China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Vietnam, Cuba and nine others to fill seats on the Human Rights Council.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Government Delays Ending State of Emergency and Curfew
item.description: Egypt’s interim government said a state of emergency, as well as a nighttime curfew, would remain in place until it had received formal notice of a judicial ruling Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: 4,000 More Peacekeepers for Somalia
item.description: The United Nations Security Council authorized an increase of peacekeepers in Somalia so that the force could better fight the Shabab militants.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Imprisoned Punk Protester Is in Siberia
item.description: A human rights ombudsman said the Pussy Riot band member Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, whose whereabouts were previously unknown, had been transferred to a Siberian prison.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: House Stalls Trade Pact Momentum
item.description: Nearly half of the members of the House of Representatives have signed letters signaling opposition to “fast track” authority for a trade pact with Pacific Rim nations.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: In Kuala Lumpur, Malaysians protested a trade proposal between the United States and a dozen Pacific Rim countries.

item.title: Iran Talks Face Resistance in U.S. Congress
item.description: The Obama administration is trying stop efforts in Congress to impose new sanctions on Iran that the White House fears could derail negotiations to freeze the country’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: Chinese Leader Gets More Sway on the Economy and Security
item.description: President Xi Jinping wants to shift the economy away from heavy polluting industries, volatile social divisions and state-driven infrastructure spending.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, center, and other Chinese Communist Party leaders voted on policy measures as the Central Committee met on Tuesday in Beijing.

item.title: Sports of The Times: Doping Rules Are Tougher Only if Applied
item.description: The World Anti-Doping Agency’s decision to change its ban for athletes caught doping from two years to four has focused attention on the diligence of countries’ drug testing programs.
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR
item.media:description: The Jamaican sprinter Asafa Powell tested positive in a recent in-competition drug test.

item.title: Scorned by His Fellow Musicians, a Refugee From Iran Was Looking to Kill
item.description: Ali Akbar Mohammadi Rafie, who killed three men from his homeland on Monday and then took his own life, had grown increasingly isolated before the shootings.
item.dc:creator: By VIVIAN YEE and J. DAVID GOODMAN
item.media:credit: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pooya Hosseini, a member of the Free Keys, the band that once included Mr. Rafie, made a visit on Tuesday to 318 Maujer Street in Brooklyn, the site of the killings.

item.title: As the Living Receive Aid, Bodies Remain Uncollected in the Philippines
item.description: Although the authorities have been criticized for not doing more to collect remains, the dead were not considered carriers of germs that can infect the living.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: People waited Tuesday at the airport in Tacloban, the Philippines, to be evacuated from one of the areas hardest hit by a typhoon. Transportation and food supplies were devastated by the storm.

item.title: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims Who Can’t Get Aid, or Get Out
item.description: International officials expressed worry that bottlenecks and delays could prevent emergency supplies from reaching millions of victims for days.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents waiting inside a damanged airport to get to a government plane out of Tacloban City.

item.title: New U.N. Brigade’s Aggressive Stance in Africa Brings Success, and Risks
item.description: The Force Intervention Brigade routed rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a departure from peacekeepers’ usually passive approach.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Martin Kobler, center, a United Nations official, in the Democratic Republic of Congo recently. He said, “You have to find new instruments to restore the peace.”

item.title: Bloomberg Says News Service Did Not Kill Articles on China
item.description: Bloomberg News, a unit of the company owned by Michael R. Bloomberg, was accused of withholding articles that were unflattering to Chinese officials.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO
item.media:description: Michael R. Bloomberg said of the Bloomberg news service’s coverage, “No one thinks that we are wusses.”

item.title: Private Donors’ Funds Add Wild Card to War in Syria
item.description: The flow of millions of dollars in private money to extremist fighters has added an unpredictable factor to the war, analysts say, exacerbating divisions in the opposition.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign outside Kuwait City directing donors to a house used by Sheikh Shafi al-Ajmi to raise funds for Islamist rebels in Syria.

item.title: Algiers Journal: Born in Protest, a Soccer Team Hailed by the People and the Government
item.description: Mouloudia, founded nearly 100 years ago and Algeria’s most popular soccer team, was a force in the war for independence from France and is a powerful political tool.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An officer stood guard during a match between Mouloudia and a visiting club in Algiers last month.

item.title: John Tavener Dies at 69; Composer With Eye on God
item.description: Mr. Tavener, a composer informed by Orthodox Christianity, was heard throughout the world in his elegy, performed at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales.
item.dc:creator: By ALLAN KOZINN
item.media:credit: Steve Forrest/Insight-Visual for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British composer John Tavener in 2007 at his home in Dorset, in southern England.

item.title: Czech Politician Faces Claims of Aiding Secret Police
item.description: Andrej Babis, a billionaire who was a surprise kingmaker in recent elections, denies allegations that he was an agent for the reviled Czechoslovak secret police.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.media:description: The billionaire Andrej Babis denies claims he was a Communist-era secret police agent.

item.title: Israeli Move Over Housing Poses a Threat to Peace Talks
item.description: The lead Palestinian negotiator said the talks would end if Israel did not withdraw its call for new plans for housing in West Bank settlements.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The contentious E1 settlement area, left, is a vast, hilly expanse sitting between East Jerusalem and the West Bank settlement of Maale Adumim, right.

item.title: Economix Blog: The Inequality of Climate Change
item.description: The typhoon that ravaged the Philippines underscores what many development experts say is a cruel truth about climate change: It will hit the world’s poorest the hardest.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Changes in physical and biological systems and surface temperature, 1970-2004. Source: .
